div.head: ❧ By the King.
¶ A Proclamation touching the Surueying of the Seacoales of Newcastle, Sunderland, and Blythe.
div.p: FOrasmuch as the Commoditie of Seacoales of Newcastle vpon Tyne, Sunderland, and Blythe, within Our County of Northumberland, and Our County Palatine of Duresme, and the places thereunto adioyning, is a merchandize so vsefull, aswell in respect of the decay of wood already much wasted within this Our Realme of England, as also in respect of the transporting of them into forreigne parts to the aduancement of the Trade of this Kingdome, by the natiue commodity thereof, as that We haue thought it a matter well worthy Our speciall care, and much importing the state and welfare of this Our Common wealth, to vphold and maintaine the reputation and value of the same:

And whereas vpon Information and Complaint made vnto Vs heretofore, of the many and great deceits, and abuses, done and offered vnto Vs, and Our louing Subiects of this Our Realme of England by the Oastmen, Diggers, Getters, and Traders for Coale in the Coalemines of Newcastle, Sunderland, and Blythe aforesaid, and in all other places thereabouts, where the said Coales are digged and gotten, who in stead of good and merchantable Coales, send and bring vnto Our citie of London, and other parts of this Our Realme of England, and elsewhere, much Blacke earth, Drosse, Slate, and other vnmerchantable stuffe, which ariseth in, and about the said Coale-pittes, and is blacke like Coales, but not fit to burne, or Fuelable, and which the Oastmen, Diggers and Traders in Coales, doe well knowe, and yet doe purposely and voluntarily mingle the said deceitfull Blacke earth, Slate, Stone, and other vnfuelable stuffe amongst their good Coales, and sell and vtter the same for good and merchantable Coales, to the enriching of themselues, the preiudice of the Common-wealth, and the disgrace, and discredite of the said commodity in forreigne parts:

Wee thereupon taking into Our princely care and consideration, the qualitie of these abuses, and the consequences thereof, and much desiring a reformation of the same, yet Our care was, that the said abuses informed of, might first euidently appeare to bee such indeede, as they were alleadged to be, and the Offendors and their manner of offending discouered thereby, the better to finde out a remedy to preuent the like inconueniences, and to that end Wee did referre the examination of the same, first vnto some of Our Counsell learned in the Law at that time, who made certificate
thereof vnto Vs, and afterwards the Lords, and others of Our Priuie Counsell, vpon Petition exhibited vnto them by the Traders, and Laders of Seacoales at Newcastle, did take consideration of the same, and did order and appoint a tryall thereof, to bee had by a legall proceeding in Our high Court of Starre-chamber; vpon which triall, as also by the certificate aforesaid, it did then appeare, That there were, and are seuerall sorts of Coales, at, or neere Newcastle, some of tenne and eleuen shillings the great Chaldron, which are good and fuelable, and some of foure or fiue shillings the chaldron, which are drossie, and vnfuelable, fit onely for Salt-pannes, and Lime-kilnes; And that albeit there are sufficient store of good Coales to serue the Realme of England, and forreigne vent, without any mixture of the bad, yet neuerthelesse the Oastmen, and Traders for Coales at Newcastle, (claiming a speciall Priuiledge to sell them to the Shippers) haue vsed voluntarily to mingle the good Coales with the bad and drossie Coales, and to sell them so mingled to gether at the highest prices of tenne and eleuen shillings the chaldron, warranting them all to bee of the best Coales, by this meanes gaining almost halfe in halfe, which said voluntary mingling, and corrupting of Coales, Our said Court of Starre-chamber found to be a great and generall abuse and enormity to Our whole Realme, and very meete to be suppressed, reformed and punished, And did then decree, that the offendors, then the Defendants, should be committed to the Fleete, and fyned twenty pounds a piece.

And to the end that others might take notice, how far Our said Court did mislike, & condemne the said fraud and deceit, and their resolution to punish the same, The said Court thought fit, and so ordered, that the said Decree should bee publiquely read in open market, in the towne of Newcastle, where the said offence had beene committed, on two Market dayes, when most people were assembled, for the more publique declaration thereof to the Countrey, as by the said Decree more at large appeareth.

And whereas, notwithstanding that exemplary punishment, inflicted by Our said Court of Starre-chamber, as aforesaid, and the publique manifestation thereof, before declared, Our desire for a due reformation of the abuses before mentioned, did not take that effect which Wee expected, but the deceits, and abuses aforesaid, did rather more and more increase, insomuch as the Masters, Wardens, Assistants, and companies of Wood-mongers, Brewers, Chaundlers, and other Traders in London for Newcastle-Coales, became petitioners vnto Vs, crauing Our gracious fauour and assistance for the due reformation thereof; whereupon, and vpon consideration againe thereof had, by seuerall committees from the Lords, and others of Our Priuie Councell, at seuerall times, vpon seuerall petitions exhibited, aswell by the Wood-mongers, Brewers, Chaundlers, and Traders for Coales in London, and other Porte Townes within this Our Realme of England, as also by the Shippers, Masters, & Owners of Ships, trading for Coales from Newcastle aforesaid, and vpon suruey, and examination of the true state of those Coale-mines, and Coale-pits, by their Lordships speciall directions had, and taken, it appeared, and was found, that the abuses and deceits aforesaid, (notwithstanding the pretences to the contrary) did yet continue, and that there was no meanes so probable for reformation of the same, as the vigilant care and paines of faithfull and industrious persons, to be imployed and attendant at the Coale-pits, and Wharfes, of Newcastle, and other places adiacent, and they to be furnished with absolute authority from Vs, for the prohibiting, and preuenting of the deceitfull mixture of Coales, by the Oastmen and others, and to make certificates of the goodnesse, or badnesse of Coales, for the buyers direction, and auoiding of deceits therein not discernable by the eye; And the said Lords, and others of Our Priuie Councell, did humbly propose vnto Vs, diuers limitations, orders, and prouisions, which they conceiued fit and obseruable in the execution of the same. Wee therefore hauing well considered, and
• pprooued of the propositions, and prouisions before mentioned, and of the great care, and extraordinary charge vsed in the discouery of the abuses aforesaid, and of prouiding, propounding, and setling a fit and apt meanes for the reformation thereof, haue graciously beene pleased, not onely to reuoke all former Letters Patents, by Vs made for that purpose, (they in some particulars being found to bee defectiue,) but by other Our Letters Patents vnder. Our great Seale of England, bearing date the twentieth day of September, in the one and twentieth yeere of Our Reigne of England, France and Ireland, and of Scotland the seuen and fiftieth, Haue for Vs, Our Heires and successours, straitly ordained, established, charged and prohibited, that thereafter none of the said low prized Coales, called Panne coales, nor Drosse, blacke Earth, or other vnmerchantable stuffe whatsoeuer, shall by any of the said Oastmen, Owners, and Diggers of the said Newcastle Coales, or by any other person or persons whatsoeuer, be mingled, mixed, or put amongst good and merchantable Coales, nor shall at any time, or times hereafter, being so mingled, be brought, or transported into any the Ports, or places of this Our Realme of England, or transported into any the parts beyond the Seas, vpon paine of Our high displeasure, and other the penalties therein contained.

And for the better obseruation and performance of Our will and pleasure in the same, We haue in, and by Our said Letters Patents, made, ordained, appointed, constituted, and erected an office to haue perpetuall continuance, which for euer hereafter shall be, and shall be called the office of Surueyour of Coales to be shipped at Newcastle, Sunderland, and Blythe, or any of them, or at any other places adiacent, to be brought and transported to Our citie of London, or other places of this Our Kingdome of England, or any the parts beyond the Seas; Which said office, We, of Our especiall Grace, certaine knowledge, and meere motion, and at the request and nomination of Our late right trustie and right welbeloued Couzen and Councellour, Lodowicke Duke of Richmond and Lenox, since deceased, Haue by Our said Letters Patents graunted vnto Our trusty and welbeloued Sir Robert Sharpeigh Knight, and Alexander Haitely Esquire, to hold to them and their Assignes, for the space of one and twentie yeeres, with such Fees and Allowances, and such Cautions, Directions, Limitations, and Promsions for the execution thereof, as by the said Lords, and others of Our priuie Councell haue beene thought fit and aduised, as in, and by the said Letters Patents nore at large may appeare.

Now, to the end Our louing Subiects may perceiue with what care and caution Our selfe and Our priuie Councell, haue proceeded in this businesse for the welfare of Our people, and the preuenion of all future inconuenience that may arise in a businesse of this nature, and to the end such as haue heretofore beene Delinquents in the premisses, may hereby take notice of Our pleasure, and not plead their ignorance, as an excuse for their misdemeanour; Wee haue thought fit hereby to make manifest and declare such speciall and necessary obseruations and directions, tending to the reformation aforesaid, and contained in Our said Letters Patents, as are most meet to be published, and of necessitie to be obserued in the performance of the same; And doe therefore signifie and declare Our will and pleasure to be, and We doe hereby straitly charge, prohibite and command, aswell all and euery the said Oastmen, and all others trading for Seacoales at Newcastle, Sunderand and Blythe aforesaid, and the places adiacent, or working thereon, or imployed in or about the •… me, as also all and euery the Masters and Owners of any Shippes, Boats, Hoyes, Crayer or •… her vessels imployed for the conueying, transporting, or bringing the said Seacoales vnto Our • id citie of London, or vnto any other Ports or places of this Our realme of England, or into any the • rts beyond the Seas, That they, or any of them presume not to endeauour or attempt at any • ne or times hereafter, directly or indirectly by any practise or deuise whatsoeuer, to mingle or mixe
any of the said low prized and vnfuellable Coales, Drosse, Slate, Blacke-earth, or other vnmerchantable Coales, not well picked or wealled, amongst, or with any the said good, pure and fuelable Coales, neither shall buy, lade, or fraight into any their Ships, Boats, or other vessels any of the said drossy, and vnmerchantable Coales, as aforesaid, mingled with the said good and merchantable Coales; Nor shall at any time or times hereafter conuey or transport any of the said base and vnmerchantable Coales in any ship or other vessell whatsoeuer, in which the said good and merchantable Coales are conueyed or transported, nor together with the said good Coales; And that no woodmongers, wharfingers, merchants, or other traders in Coales whatsoeuer, shal at any time or times hereafter, lay or cause to be laid any of the said baser sort of Coales vpon one and the selfe same wharffe, together with the said good Coales.

And further, that none of the said Masters or Owners of Ships or other vessels, shall transport or conuey any such mingled Coales, or any other Coales, of what nature or qualitie soeuer, without Certificate from the Officer or Officers of Vs, Our Heires and Successors appointed for the surueying of Seacoales, as aforesaid, their Deputie or Deputies, vnder the Seale of their said Office, testifying the goodnesse, qualitie, or badnesse of his and their Coales, and the quantitie thereof first had and obtained; And that no woodmonger, wharfinger, merchant, or trader in Seacoales in Our said citie of London, or in any other place or places whatsoeuer, within this Our realme of England, shall at any time or times hereafter, presume or goe about to buy or take any Coales of any Shipper, Owner or Master of any Ship, or other vessell whatsoeuer, that shall not shew and produce such certificate, as aforesaid, vpon paine of Our high displeasure, and such other paines, penalties and imprisonments, as by the Lawes and Statutes of this Our realme of England, or by Our prerogatiue Royall, can or may be inflicted vpon them for their disobedience and contempt of Our Royall commandement in this behalfe.

And Wee will, and Our pleasure is, that for the more certaine preuention of the abuses aforesayd, All and euery the Oastmen, Fitters, and Coale-owners, Staithes-men, Merchants for Coales, and all and singuler Masters and Owners of Shippes or other vessels, when they or any of them shall agree or contract together for any Coales to be conueyed or transported, as aforesaid, that they and euery of them, by themselues, their seruants, deputies or agents, shall from time to time deliuer, or cause to be deliuered vnto the said officer or officers of Vs, Our Heires and Successors or his or their deputie, or deputies for the time being, true notes and tickets in writing, testifying the sortes and quantities of all such Coales, as from time to time they shall contract for, and from what Staithes they shall be serued and sent aboard, before the lading and clearing of the same, in such sort and manner, as by Our Letters Patents before recited is directed and set downe.

And whereas, in and by Our Letters Patents aforesaid, and vpon the offer of the Woodmongers, Brewers and other Traders for Coales in Our citie of London, and by the aduise of Our said Priuie Councell, Wee haue granted a Fee of foure pence vpon euery great chaldron of Coales to be conueyed and transported, as aforesaid, (those that are to be transported beyond the Seas by strangers only excepted) to be paid vnto the officer or officers of Vs, Our Heires and Successors for surueying of Seacoales, for their paines and charges in surueying of them, and making certificates, and keeping Registers concerning the same; Our pleasure is, that all and euery Masters and Owners of ships or other vessels, shall from time to time, vpon their receiuing of their Certificates aforesaid, pay or cause to be paid vnto the said Officer or Officers of Vs, Our Heires or Successors, their Deputies or Assignes the said Fee of foure pence for euery great chaldron of Coales, by them to be conueyed or transported, as aforesaid.

And that the said Woodmongers, Wharfingers, common Brewers, Dyers, Chaundlers, and others buying Coales from the Shippes, or other vessels, and selling the same againe in grosse,
or by retaile, shall well and duely answere, and pay vnto the sayd Shipper, Master, or Owner of any Shippe, or other vessell, producing such certificate, the said Fee, or Allowance of foure pence vpon euery great Chaldron of Coales, by him or them payd vnto Our sayd Officer or Officers, as aforesaid, without inhansing the prices of the said Coales vnto Our louing Subiects, that shall buy them againe for their priuate vse and expence, according to the aduice and order of the Lords, and others of Our Priuy Counsell therein.

And Our further will and pleasure is, and Wee doe hereby straitly charge and command the said Sir Robert Sharpeigh, and Alexander Haiteley, vnto whom Wee haue granted the said Office of Surueyour of the Seacoales, as aforesaid, That they, the said Sir Robert Sharpeigh, and Alexander Haiteley, their Executors, Administrators, and Assignes, by themselues or their sufficient deputies or seruants, doe, & shall from time to time, during the said terme in Our said Letters Patents to them therof made, contained, faithfully, industriously, and carefully endeauour to see Our will and pleasure in the premisses strictly & duely performed & obserued; And to make true certificates, from time to time, of the quality and quantity of the said Coales, for the preuention of the abuses aforesaid, according to our particular directions in Our Letters Patents aforesaid to them giuen. And if at any time or times it shall happen, that the sayd Surueyour or Surueyours, their deputie or deputies, shall wittingly and willingly make any false certificate, and it be found at any shippe or other vessell, that the said Coales are contrary to such certificate, corrupted and mingled, and not such in trueth, as they are certified to be; Then Our pleasure is, That the said Surueyours, their Executours, Administrators or Assignes, so wittingly and willingly falsifying the trust Wee haue reposed in them, shall make sufficient restitution and satisfaction vnto such Merchant, Wood-monger, Wharfinger, and other Traders in Coales, for the Losse and Dammage that he or they shall sustaine thereby.

And lastly, Wee doe hereby will and command all and singuler Maiors, Iustices of Peace, Customers, Comptrollers, Searchers, Waiters, Baylifes, Constables, Officers, and Ministers of Vs, Our Heires and Successours, to whom it shall, or may appertaine, that they, and euery of them, be from time to time, aiding and assisting vnto the said Sir Robert Sharpeigh, and Alexander Haiteley, their Executors, Administrators, Deputies and Assignes, & to all other the Officers of Vs, Our Heires and Successors in this behalfe, in all lawfull manner, for the due execution of Our seruice herein, according to Our pleasure herein signified.

And that they, and euery of them, doe from time to time, cause diligent suruey, and inquiry to be made within their seuerall precincts, limits, and iurisdictions, of all offenders in this behalfe, and together with Our said Officer, or Officers, to make speedy certificate of their names without partiality, or conniuence vnto the Lords and others of Our Priuie Councell, or to Our Attourney generall for the time being, that they may be proceeded against in Our Court of Starre-chamber, or otherwise, according to their demerites. And Our will and pleasure is, That aswell the said Lords, and others of Our Priuie Councell, as Our Attourney generall for the time being, vse all care and diligence, to punish with seuerity, aswell the partiality, negligence, and remisnesse of the said Maiors, Iustices of Peace, Surueyors of Coales, and other Officers aforesaid, in not making due suruey, or certificate, as aforesaid, as the contemptuous behauiour of such, as shall presume to violate this Our Proclamation, or the Letters Patents before recited.
